We studied the effect of femtosecond (FS) laser-texturing of 316 L stainless steel (SS) plates on their oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Here, the FS laser texturing is adapted to create oxyhydroxide layers with dimple structures on the pristine SS (denoted as B-SS) electrode. The single-side textured SS electrode is represented as FSSS-SS, and the double-side textured SS electrode is described as FSDS-SS. Upon FS laser texturing, significant elements variations of diffraction and photoelectron peak intensities profoundly influence their OER activity. As a result, the above electrode's OER overpotentials in 6.0 M potassium hydroxide (KOH) follow the order of B-SS (257 mV) > FSSS-SS (254 mV) > FSDS-SS (251 mV). However, the above order is reversed in the case of Tafel slopes viz., FSDS-SS (56 mV dec−1) > FSSS-SS (50 mV dec−1) > B-SS (47 mV dec−1). The FS laser textured electrodes exhibit a favorable OER activity regarding overpotential and current density. Besides, based on the Tafel slope analysis, the B-SS electrode shows accelerated OER kinetics. These adverse results may be due to the dimple morphology, reconfiguration of elemental composition, O/Ni/Fe ratios, and the passive nature of catalyst layers, which define the OER performance of SS electrodes. Introduction Today's most burning issues are the environment and energy. On a global scale, energy demand has been increasing rapidly and is expected to grow twice within the next 15 years [1]. Right away, most of the world's energy requirement is fulfilled by fossil fuels, whose sources are inadequate [2]. Therefore, generating energy through renewables has been perceived as a promising approach for substantially reducing our dependence on vastly toxin energy resources [3]. Hydrogen (H2) has the qualities of being pollution-free, environmentally safe, and sustainable. Thus, it is an alternative to pollutant fossil fuels [4,5]. In light of the above, water oxidation is considered the most straightforward technique among several hydrogen production methods. It has become highly prevalent, being its prominent role in metal-air batteries, water splitting, and fuel cells [6,7]. However, the hydrogen production efficiency is comparatively decreased because of the highly slothful anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) overpotential [8]. Generally, RuO2 and IrO2 noble metal-based catalysts are standard OER electrocatalysts. Despite this, Ru and Ir are comparatively rare and expensive, limiting their widespread application [9]. Consequently, developing low-cost, efficient, and frequently available non-precious metal catalysts (primarily Ni, Fe, Co, Mn, W, and Mo) to substitute noble metal-based electrocatalysts has been demanding [10]. To this end, stainless steel (SS) with components viz., Fe, Mn, Ni, Cr, and the (oxy)hydroxides of these elements has drawn attention as the unconventional anode material for the OER electrocatalysts [11–13]. Employing SS as an OER catalyst can bypass the number of preparation steps and the tedious use of additives and binders. Furthermore, the in-situ formation of OER stimulants on the conductive electrodes offers superior electrocatalytic activity and enhanced stability. Hence, SS is inclined to be a more relevant electrode for alkaline water electrolyzers due to its merits, like its low price and increased production capacity. Recent studies showed that specific surface structural and compositional variation techniques could form OER-active surface layers on the SS electrode [13–16]. Zhang et al. [11] validated that a pervasive stainless steel mesh (SSM) galvanized by a cathodization shows remarkably shallow overpotentials of 275 and 319 mV to achieve 10 and 100 mA cm−2 of current densities in 1.0 M potassium hydroxide (KOH), respectively. Schaffer et al. [17] examined the influence of Cl2 treatment on the OER activity of a 304 SS electrode. As a result of this treatment, AISI 304 steel became an effective water-splitting electrocatalyst at pH 7 and 13. The anodic OER overpotential might be decreased to 260 mV at 1.5 mA cm−2 in 0.1 M KOH. These observations suggest that modified SS-based electrodes exhibit better water oxidation performance than unmodified SS substrates, and their OER properties are compared and presented in Table S1. Even though these practices can improve the OER performance of SS-based substrates, the procedure encompasses highly erosive solutions, adverse gasses, lasting pressure, high temperatures, and highly energy-intense strategies [18]. Recently, ultrafast laser processing has been a powerful and flexible tool that allows tuning the essential chemical compositions for all materials acquired by producing self-oriented micro- and nano-scale structures [19]. For instance, Cai et al. [20] revealed that two-step laser writing and an in-situ activated stainless steel mesh exhibit remarkable OER performance with a slightly less Tafel slope of 35 mV dec−1 and a small overpotential of 262 mV. Moreover, Zhang et al. [21] demonstrated that the hydrothermal treatment might synthesize an effective 3D cross-linked nanosheet comprising NiFe hydroxide over 316 SS mesh in a melted salt solution of NH4HCO3/NiCl2. Our previous study utilized a cost-effective pulsed laser corroding approach to improve the OER activity of 316 SS with honeycomb-patterned Fe-Cr-Ni (oxy)hydroxide corroded layers. Although the double-side laser-rusted SS (DSLR-SS) electrode had a shallow Tafel slope (52 mV dec−1), it had an elevated overpotential (382 mV) in 1.0 M KOH [22]. While laser texturing performs well, there is still room for further insights. To the author's knowledge, the femtosecond (FS) laser texturing of SS toward OER is a less charted area. In this study, we assessed the effects of FS laser structuring on the OER performance of 316 L SS electrodes. The pristine and modified electrode's chemical compositions and formation of the surface layers are evaluated by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and field-emission scanning electron microscopy with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (FE-SEM/EDS). The correlation between the OER activity, morphologies, and chemical compositions, is investigated. These results demonstrate that the FS laser texturing has negatively impacted the OER performance of the SS electrodes related to the changes in their physical and chemical properties. Experimental Materials For this experiment, 316L-type SS plates (10 mm in length, 10 mm in breadth, and 0.2 mm in thickness) with a chemical composition of Fe (69.97%), Cr (16.17%), Ni (10.06%), Mo (2.04%), Mn (1.08%), Si (0.62%), P (0.03%), and C (0.02%) were obtained from POSCO, Republic of Korea. The SS plates were first polished with different sandpaper grades: #600, #800, and #1200. Afterward, they were ultrasonically cleansed with ethanol, acetone, and double distilled water for 15 mins and preserved at 60 °C in a hot air oven. KOH electrolyte (6.0 M) was made using KOH pellets (ACS reagent, >85% Sigma Aldrich, South Korea) and deionized water. Femtosecond (FS) laser texturing Over the SS plates, dimple structures were developed using an FS laser (PHAROS PH1-SP-1mJ) under the following working conditions: a wavelength of 1033 nm, a pulse energy of 1 mJ, a pulse frequency of 10 kHz, and a moving speed of 500 mm/s. It took 18 min to complete a single-side texturing, and the final electrodes were denoted as FSSS-SS. However, it took 36 min to complete double-side texturing, and the ablated electrodes are represented as FSDS-SS. The pristine SS electrode without ablation is labeled as B-SS. Structural analysis The elemental compositions and morphology were accomplished through field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE–SEM; SIGMA, Carl Zeiss) in conjunction with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS; Oxford Instruments). The crystalline structures were acquired utilizing D8-Advance, Bruker-AXS X-ray diffraction (XRD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; K-alpha+, ThermoFisher Scientific) established the chemical compositions and valence states. The binding energies were standardized compared to the nonessential C 1 s signal at 284.8 eV. For clarity purposes, the 2p3/2 sub-state bands are described alone. Electrochemical measurements A three-electrode arrangement was employed to perform the electrochemical analyses. B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes act as working electrodes, and a platinum (Pt) wire and mercury/mercury oxide (Hg/HgO) (6.0 M KOH) were utilized as the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were recorded at a sweep rate of 5 mV s−1 to evaluate the OER activity. The non-faradaic region cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves recorded at diverse sweep rates of 10–100 mV s−1 with a potential variation of 0.1 V vs. Hg/HgO were used to measure the electrochemical double-layer capacitances (Cdl). The linear slope is twofold the Cdl. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) curves at the onset potential were recorded at a frequency varying from 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz by passing an AC voltage with 5 mV amplitude. The double-layer capacitance (Cdl), overpotential (η), and Tafel slope (b) valuations were derived based on our previous study [22]. The potentials were adjusted to the RHE scale, where it was deemed essential. Results and discussion Surface characterization of the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes The B-SS electrode surface is relatively flat, with metallic gray color. While after the FS laser texturing, the color of the B-SS electrode transformed from metallic gray to dark brown, signifying the formation of oxide layers across the FSSS-SS and FSDS-SS electrode surfaces (see Fig. 1 a–c, insets). The FS dimple textured surface is significantly rough, has many voids, and is covered by dense microparticles with fewer nanoparticles. The Fe content (at.%) is slightly less in the case of FS laser textured electrodes and follows the order of B-SS (63.01) > FSSS-SS (60.44) > FSDS-SS (60.17) as like of Ni. However, the O content (at.%) is high in the case of the FSSS-SS (8.17) and FSDS-SS (9.54) electrodes, compared to B-SS (5.48) (see Fig. 1d–f). This implies that more (oxy)hydroxide layers are formed on the surface of the FS laser-structured electrodes, which is further supported by its relatively higher O/Ni (upper rows) and O/Fe (lower rows) ratios. Similar to the O content (at.%), the Cr content (at.%) of the FS laser-structured electrodes is high, which is anticipated to create a rough surface. The observed trend indicates that FS laser texturing may facilitate OER-inert Cr element enrichment. The Cr-enriched passive film's formation is attributed to Fe selective dissolution, leaving behind Cr augmented in the passive film [8]. In the XRD spectrum of the B-SS electrode (Fig. 2 a), there are four diffraction peaks positioned at 43.65° (111), 44.52°(110), 50.74°(200), and 74.62°(220) because of the characteristic metallic Fe, Cr, and Ni alloys [14]. The peak intensity of the austenite (non-magnetic; 43.65°) is higher for the FSSS-SS and FSDS-SS electrodes. While their ferrite (magnetic; 44.52°) peak intensity is lower than in the B-SS electrode [23,24]. These results suggest that FS laser texturing creates passive non-magnetic sites for improved reagent adsorption [25]. The XP survey spectra depicted in Fig. 2b disclose the entity of Fe, Cr, Ni, and O components, which agree with the EDS outcomes (see Fig. 1d–f). Generally, Fe, Cr, and Ni are the main metallic elements found in SS electrodes, but corresponding oxides may also form on the SS surface because of working atmospheric conditions [14]. The chemical bonding states of the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes are extracted from the deconvoluted spectrum of Fe 2p, Cr 2p, and Ni 2p binding energy regions are presented in Figs. 3-5 . Besides, Tables 1-3 represent the tailored parameters. For the B-SS electrode (Fig. 3a and Table 1), the Fe 2p band is deconvoluted into Fe0 and Fe3+. Therefore, Fe3+ components imply that the B-SS electrode surface partly comprises Fe-based oxides/(oxy)hydroxides [14]. However, the Fe 2p bands of the FSSS-SS (Fig. 3b) and FSDS-SS (Fig. 3c) electrodes are attributed mainly to the Fe3+ and Fe4+ components. In comparison, the relative area of Fe4+ species in the FSDS-SS electrode becomes high than in the FSSS-SS electrode. These observations suggest that the FS laser substantially oxidized the maximum Fe0 into its higher valence species [26,27]. In the Cr 2p region, the B-SS (Fig. 4 a and Table 2 ) show only the Cr3+ oxide/(oxy)hydroxide peaks. At the same time, the FSSS-SS electrode (Fig. 4b) electrodes show peaks for both Cr3+ and Cr6+. On the other hand, the Cr 2p band for the FSDS-SS (Fig. 4c) electrode is attributed mainly to Cr3+, Cr4+, and Cr6+species [28]. This indicates that the Cr component remains even after FS laser texturing. Moreover, the Cr is oxidized to its higher valence species upon double-side laser texturing. As shown in Fig. 5 and Table 3 , Ni0 and Ni2+peaks are observed for the B-SS (Fig. 5a) electrode because of the alloyed Ni with other electropositive metals. In comparison, the Ni 2p bands of FSSS-SS (Fig. 5b) and FSDS-SS (Fig. 5c) electrodes with major peaks correspond to Ni2+ and Ni3+ species. The close vicinity of Ni3+ turns higher, implying numerous Ni3+ species be found on the FSDS-SS electrode surface [14,29,30]. The XPS results suggest that the FS laser-textured electrodes contain more multivalent oxides and (oxy)hydroxides. Electrochemical characterization of the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes The relationship between the experimental OER kinetic parameters and the inherent oxide layer is studied by practicing CV [31]. The apparent differences in the passive film formation are explained by comparing the cyclic voltammogram of the studied electrodes recorded at 5 mV s−1 (Fig. 6 a). Generally, two cathodic and four anodic peaks are identified through the initial oxidation of newly refined electrodes. Nevertheless, up to five cathodic and six anodic peaks for the same system have been observed; this inconsistency may arise from different working conditions (i.e., pre-treatments, lower and upper voltammetric thresholds, and sweeping rates) utilized by various researchers [32]. The reviewed literature has yet to report the peaks A5, A6, C5, C4, and C3 [33]. Thus, four (A1–A4) anodic peaks and two (C1, C2) cathodic peaks arose through the preliminary oxidation steps, revealing surface redox reactions compelling certain oxy-iron species. At peak A1, the electrochemical transposition of adsorbed hydrogen starts with the adsorption of OH− ions [31,34]. (1) Fe + OH− → FeOH (ads.) + e− (2) FeH (ads.) → Fe + H+ + e− Whereas, at peak A2 the thin layer of Fe(II) hydroxide (Fe(OH)2) or oxide (FeO) formation may occur. (3) FeOH (ads.) + OH− → Fe(OH)2 + e− (4) FeOH (ads.) + OH− → FeO + H2O + e− In the dispersed and outer hydrated zones of Fe(OH)2/FeO layer, the redox transmutation of Fe(II) or Fe(III) takes place in the anodic peak A3 and its cathodic supplement C2. The processes mentioned above are to be expected for the thick film formation. (5) Fe(OH)2 + OH− → FeOOH + H2O + e− In the compact, inner anhydrous zone of the passive layer, the redox transformation of Fe(II)/Fe(III) occurs at peak A4, including Fe2O3, FeOOH, and Fe3O4. The corresponding reduction of the anhydrous, tight area might occur at peak C1 [31,34]. (6) FeO.FeOOH + H2O + 3e− → Fe + FeO2 2− + H2O + OH− A significant observation is that for the FS laser textured electrodes, peaks A1/A2 decrease/increase markedly compared to the B-SS electrode. By contrast, the anodic peaks A3 and A4 and the cathodic complements C2 and C1 of the FS laser textured electrodes increase predominantly over the B-SS electrode. This suggests higher valence Fe species formation on the FS laser-textured electrode surface than on the B-SS electrode surface, which validates the EDS and XPS results. For further insights into the peak positions, the representative cyclic voltammograms inscribed in 6.0 M KOH at various scan rates of the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes are presented in Fig. 6b-d, respectively. Fig. 7 a represents the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrode polarization curves. The overpotential needed by the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes to accomplish a current density of 10 mA cm−2 is 257, 254, and 251 mV, respectively. The estimated overpotential values indicate that catalytic activity reduces in the order of FSDS-SS > FSSS-SS > B-SS. This overpotential loss may arise from a high-level imperfection thickness for FS laser-textured electrodes [31]. The Fig. 7a inset reveals that near the onset potential for the FS laser textured electrodes, the current density associated with the formation of Cr3+/Cr6+ or Ni2+/Ni3+ or both increases [35]; this correlates well with the XPS results. Fig. 7b shows that even though the FSDS-SS electrode exhibits a marginally lower overpotential, it offers a slightly higher Tafel slope (56 mV dec−1) than its counterparts. The closest possible approximation is that the oxygen evolution rate is less for the FSDS-SS electrode than the FSSS-SS and B-SS electrodes do. As per the report of Lyons et al. [31], in some circumstances, an oxide charge migration barrier alters the experimental OER Tafel slope values (oxygen evolution kinetics). This can be associated with strongly bounded inner passive Fe oxide films. Subsequently, the vital energy required for the ion passage in the tight passive film usually is relatively high. Following earlier reports, these contradictory results between the studied electrodes might be due to the difference in the conductivity around the electrocatalytic boundary, surface coverage wavering, deviation in the OER path, and alteration in the rate-determining step [14,36,37]. We presume that the conductivity differences might be responsible for the ambiguous results in our case. Proposing an OER mechanism in an alkaline solution is complicated owing to the rapid four-electron transfer. Identifying an intermediary is too tricky, which is not yet wholly resolved, and remains a continued debate [38]. In general, the electrocatalytic activity is manifested by two activity markers such as the charge transfer resistance (Rct measured in the vicinity of the Faradaic region) and the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) employing double-layer capacitance (Cdl measured at the non-Faradaic part) [39]. The analogous Nyquist plots of the FSSS-SS and FSDS-SS electrodes have shown relatively higher Rct than the B-SS electrode (see Fig. 7c and Table 4 ). The Rct determined from the Nyquist plots of the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes are 37, 1677, and 1992 ohms, respectively. The higher Rct perceived with FS laser textured electrodes implies that the formation of passive layers is one reason for the higher Tafel slope, exhibiting low OER activity. Fig. 8 a-c represent the non-faradaic CV curves recorded at diverse sweep rates, which reveals the values of ECSA. The current density–scan rate plateau (Fig. 8d) fitted linear slopes are comparable to the Cdl value that could be precisely associated with the ECSA. The measured Cdl values of the B-SS, FSSS-SS, and FSDS-SS electrodes are 563, 981, and 1870 µF cm−2, respectively. As per the calculated Cdl values, the FS laser textured electrodes have higher ECSA than the B-SS electrode. However, it is inferred above that the FS laser textured electrodes are inferior in OER activity associated with the B-SS electrode. This discrepancy between Cdl and OER activity indicates that the Cdl measured in an entirely non-Faradaic region is not good merit to validate the Faradaic OER performance variations among the two electrocatalysts [39]. This clarifies that the comparatively coarsened surface ion adsorption and desorption spots are not essentially electrochemically active areas. Therefore, it is apparent that ECSA ascertained from Cdl (measured at non-Faradaic regions) is not the true ECSA of the electrode [39]. This proves that the FS laser textured electrodes (especially FSDS-SS) with high non-Faradaic capacitance are not effective as the B-SS electrode in the water oxidation process. Stability analysis of the B-SS and FSDS-SS electrodes A long-term chronoamperometric test assesses the durability of the B-SS and FSDS-SS electrodes. Fig. 9 a shows a considerable potential loss in both electrodes during 12 h of continuous electrolysis. This potential degradation reveals enhancement in the activity, possibly owing to the activation process. As a result, their morphologies changed significantly (see Fig. 9b1,b2), which is due to the formation of ferric oxide (see Fig. 9c). It implies no linear relationship between activity and stability [22]. The resulting overpotential and morphological changes with the appearance of a ferric oxide peak reveal that both the B-SS and FSDS-SS electrodes have compromising durability [40–42]. Conclusions The effect of FS laser texturing on the oxygen evolution reaction of the 316 L SS electrodes is investigated. With a relatively smooth surface and significantly higher OER kinetics, the pristine (B-SS) electrode is roughened with OER inactive layers using FS laser texturing. These roughened electrodes (single-side textured: FSSS-SS and double-side textured: FSDS-SS) exhibit lower overpotential than the B-SS electrode, which strongly disagrees with their Tafel slope trends. Considering the results from the surface and electrochemical analyses, we can conclude that elemental composition, highest Cr content (OER inert element), high O/Ni/Fe ratios, and passive film formation in the FS laser textured electrodes plausibly lead to a roughened dimple morphology. This is closely related to a high Rct, high non-Faradaic Cdl, and high non-Faradaic ECSA, with low Faradaic Cdl, thereby inferior OER performance. Therefore FS laser texturing has adversely affected the OER kinetics of the SS electrodes. coredata.dc:description: We studied the effect of femtosecond (FS) laser-texturing of 316 L stainless steel (SS) plates on their oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Here, the FS laser texturing is adapted to create oxyhydroxide layers with dimple structures on the pristine SS (denoted as B-SS) electrode. The single-side textured SS electrode is represented as FSSS-SS, and the double-side textured SS electrode is described as FSDS-SS. Upon FS laser texturing, significant elements variations of diffraction and photoelectron peak intensities profoundly influence their OER activity. As a result, the above electrode's OER overpotentials in 6.0 M potassium hydroxide (KOH) follow the order of B-SS (257 mV) > FSSS-SS (254 mV) > FSDS-SS (251 mV). However, the above order is reversed in the case of Tafel slopes viz., FSDS-SS (56 mV dec−1) > FSSS-SS (50 mV dec−1) > B-SS (47 mV dec−1). The FS laser textured electrodes exhibit a favorable OER activity regarding overpotential and current density. Besides, based on the Tafel slope analysis, the B-SS electrode shows accelerated OER kinetics. These adverse results may be due to the dimple morphology, reconfiguration of elemental composition, O/Ni/Fe ratios, and the passive nature of catalyst layers, which define the OER performance of SS electrodes.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of femtosecond laser-texturing on the oxygen evolution reaction of the stainless-steel plate
